items.description: Lower River Soar in Leicestershire
items.message:
River levels have risen at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 20/11/24.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.   
No further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 20:00 this evening, 20/11/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Ginge Brook
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but falling slowly on the Ginge Brook following persistent rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today 20/11/24, especially in the areas closest to the Ginge Brook near Steventon. The forecast is for a predominantly dry day. We expect river levels to continue to fall slowly through today. We are monitoring the situation. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by this evening, 20/11/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Leam and River Itchen
items.message: River levels are rising at the Eathorpe river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible to begin between this evening (19/11/2024) and tomorrow.  We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leam between Grandborough and Leamington including Kites Hardwick, Birdingbury, Marton, Eathorpe, Hunningham and Offchurch and the River Itchen between Southam and Marton including Long Itchington.  No further rainfall is forecast.  We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.   Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.  This message will be updated by 11:00 on 20/11/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tern and Perry catchments
items.message:
River levels are peaking at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today, Wednesday 20/11/24.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.   
No further significant rainfall is forecast in the next 48 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 17:00 on Wednesday 20/11/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message: River levels are rising at the Lilbourne river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible to begin between this evening (19/11/2024) and overnight.  We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne.   No further rainfall is forecast.  We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses.  This message will be updated by 11:00 on 20/11/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Chertsey Bourne

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
 
River levels are high on the Chertsey Bourne as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is possible today, 20/11/2024, especially in the Free Prae Road area of Chertsey. Light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high throughout the day.
 
We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
 
This message will be updated by this evening, 20/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lugg south of Leominster
items.message:
River levels are rising at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall and snow melt  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 20/11/24.  We expect flooding to affect Low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.   
No further significant rainfall is forecast until Saturday  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are .  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated  by 17:00 on 20/11/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Wednesday 20th November, and for at least the next 24hrs.  The forecast high tide at Great Yarmouth will restrict the Broads river system from draining out to sea, which will result in higher than normal water levels within the Broads. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning.   We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Thursday 21st November, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Bear Brook and tributaries in the Aylesbury area, including Wendover and Weston Turville
items.message: This flood alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. The forecast is for a predominantly dry day. River levels are forecast to continue falling through today. Avoid contact with flood water. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

items.description: Mid Bristol Avon area

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
Rising river levels throughout the afternoon may lead to flooding from 6:00 PM today 19/11/2024 in locations near the Bristol Avon, Semington Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed. Property flooding is not expected.

River levels are forecast to continue rising overnight but peak early tomorrow morning at a level of 1.5 metres. They will remain high during Wednesday 20/11/2024 so this flood alert will remain in place tomorrow. We are checking rivers for blockages and closely monitoring the situation.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. Don't put yourself or others at risk.
This message will be updated by 11:30 AM on 20/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: East Somerset Rivers

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Brue, River Sheppey, North Drain, South Drain

items.message:
The Flood Warning for the River Brue from Lovington to Highbridge, low lying properties has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible.  No property flooding is expected.
Flooding is possible when river levels are at their highest from 6:25 PM on 19/11/2024.
Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads near rivers.
Weather conditions are expected to improve throughout the evening and no further flooding is expected.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and closely monitoring the situation.
Refer to local authority website for road closures.
Don't put yourself or others at risk.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 20/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn in Gloucestershire
items.message:
River levels are rising at the Tewks. Upper Pound river gauge as a result of continued snowmelt. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Wednesday 20/11/24. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. Severn Ham, Tewkesbury starts to fill.
No further rainfall is forecast today.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 17:00 on 20/11/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Great Ouse in Northamptonshire, Oxfordshire and Buckinghamshire

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Milton Keynes, Oxfordshire, West Northamptonshire

items.message:
River levels are falling but remain high in response to recent rainfall. Flooding is possible over the next few hours, 20/11/24. Areas most at risk are those around the River Great Ouse from Brackley to Haversham, including Padbury Brook. 

The forecast is for dry weather over the next two days which will result in river levels continuing to fall. 

Take care on riverside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 6pm today, 20/11/2024.

items.description: River Leadon catchment
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Wedderburn Bridge river gauge as a result of continued snowmelt. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Wednesday 20/11/24. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Leadon. Locations that may be affected include Ledbury, Much Marcle, Staunton and Tibberton. Water may be out of bank at Upleadon Court.    
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 17:00 on 20/11/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dene in South East Warwickshire
River Brue and Glastonbury Millstream from Lovington to Highbridge, low lying properties
items.message:
The Flood Warning has now been removed. However, a Flood Alert remains in force for the wider area, so flooding of roads and low lying land is still possible.
Weather conditions are expected to improve throughout the evening and no further flooding is expected.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: The River Bure, Spixworth Beck and surrounding Becks
items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The current forecast is for no further flood risk from high tides.  Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Wednesday 20th November, and for at least the next 24hrs.  The forecast high tide at Great Yarmouth will restrict the Broads river system from draining out to sea, which will result in higher than normal water levels within the Broads. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas.  We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Thursday 21st November, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Wednesday 20th November, and for at least the next 24hrs.  The forecast high tide at Great Yarmouth will restrict the Broads river system from draining out to sea, which will result in higher than normal water levels within the Broads. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay.  We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Thursday 21st November, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Deben estuary
items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides as we are coming to the end of this series of spring high tides.  Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby including tidal River Esk
items.message: High tides and large tidal swell conditions tonight may lead to flooding from sea spray and wave overtopping. Flooding is possible on Wednesday 20/11/2024, between 8.30pm and 11:00pm. Areas most at risk include the North Sea coast from Staithes to Whitby, particularly around Sandsend. We are closely monitoring the situation and may re-issue this alert for further tides over the coming days. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 11:30pm on Wednesday 20/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: Levels are now well below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides as we are coming to the end of this series of spring high tides.  Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.60mAOD at 17:00 on 20/11/2024.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is high for this time of year at 116 cubic metres per second and is rising. We anticipate the flows to remain high for the next five days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 19:00 on 20/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Climping Seafront
items.message: Wednesday's early morning tide at 01:45 on 20/11/2024 is forecast to be lower than recent days. The weather still increases tide table values by 0.2 m. The total forecast tide is 5.81 metres Chart Datum (2.76 mAOD) at Littlehampton. Over the next five days, winds will remain fairly strong (Force 5) and with moderate waves. At the weekend, low pressure is predicted to bring very strong winds, large waves, and higher tide levels again. However, with astronomical tides falling to neaps, no more than minimal flood impacts are currently expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. We will reissue this Flood Alert if the risk of flooding increases.

items.description: Tidal areas of Littlehampton Rope Walk
items.message: Wednesday's early morning tide at 01:45 on 20/11/2024 is forecast to be lower than recent days. The weather still increases tide table values by 0.2 m. The total forecast tide is 5.81 metres Chart Datum (2.76 mAOD) at Littlehampton. Over the next five days, winds will remain fairly strong (Force 5) and with moderate waves. At the weekend, low pressure is predicted to bring very strong winds, large waves, and higher tide levels again. However, with astronomical tides falling to neaps, no more than minimal flood impacts are currently expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. items.description: Christchurch Harbour
River Thames at Trowlock Island
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides. Light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.

The next high tide is expected at Trowlock Island this afternoon (20/11/2024) at 17:30 and is forecast to reach between 4.80m and 4.90m. Flooding of low-lying land and roads is possible for this tide. The next high tide tomorrow morning (21/11/2024) at 05:30 is forecast to reach between 4.30m and 4.40m.

We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels.

This message will be updated by this evening, 20/11/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Crane

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames

items.message:
The tide and river levels have now reduced on the River Crane, though standing water and debris may still remain.
The weather is expected to remain dry for the next few days and no flooding is expected.
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: Langstone to Emsworth Harbour
items.message: This afternoon’s tide at Portsmouth (13:00 on 19/11/2024) came in 3 cm under forecast. Over the next week, tide levels are significantly lower than today. No further flood impacts are expected in this tidal sequence.

items.description: Isle of Sheppey and coast from Kemsley to Seasalter
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: This flood alert is being removed. The situation is improving and no further flooding is expected in this area. Whilst spring tides tomorrow afternoon are still likely to be high, they are unlikely to result in coastal flooding and peak tide levels will fall from Wednesday 20/11/2024 onwards. We will continue to monitor the forecast and reissue this alert if necessary.
